awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. The fellow is studying evolutionary patterns in early mammals by examining fossil jaws. Since the Mesozoic Era, or the Age of Dinosaurs, mammals have been able to expand into many different geographical locations. However, how mammals were able to do this, and when they began their expansion are still heavily debated.  The fellow will investigate this topic by collecting shape data on a large sample of fossil jaws from several natural history museums. Mammal jaws are especially informative because their shape is correlated with diet, thus providing clues about the mammals' ecologies. This research will contribute to our understanding of the origins of modern mammalian diversity. Further, the study focuses on evolutionary patterns before and after the Cretaceous-Paleogene (K-Pg) mass extinction event, thus offering information on how mammals are affected by mass extinction events. The fellow will expand the impact of this project by participating in numerous teaching, mentoring, and outreach opportunities, including the Discoveries in Geosciences Field School for K-12 teachers.
  
It is often hypothesized that early mammals experienced an adaptive radiation following one of three globally transformative events: (1) the rise of flowering plants ~80 million years ago (Ma), (2) the K-Pg mass extinction 66 Ma, and (3) the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum 56 Ma. However, previous research on these hypotheses often lack ecological data or phylogenetic considerations, prohibiting proper testing of adaptive radiations. Thus, the primary aim of this project is to use ecomorphological and biomechanical data from jaw morphologies to examine macroevolutionary patterns, allowing robust tests of evolutionary hypotheses and providing novel insight into the origins of modern mammalian diversity. The fellow will collect measurements and shape data on hundreds of fossil jaws from the Cretaceous through Eocene (145-34 Ma), utilizing paleontological collections from several natural history museums. Hypotheses on the timing of the early mammal radiation will be tested by calculating morphological disparity patterns through time and using phylogenetic modeling methods to assess potential changes in the mode of evolution at different points in time. The fellow will be trained in advanced phylogenetic comparative methods and quantitative paleontological techniques, and results from this project will be presented at scientific conferences and published in peer-reviewed journals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. David Grossnickle completed an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology working in the lab of Professor Gregory Wilson Mantilla at the University of Washington. This fellowship supported a research project centered on testing the question: did the Cretaceous-Paleogene (K-Pg) mass extinction event 66 million years ago (Ma) trigger the radiation of modern mammals? Recent studies have shown conflicting evidence for and against the oft-cited hypothesis that mammals began to adaptively radiate immediately after the K-Pg boundary, and Dr. Grossnickle sought to test this hypothesis using novel ecomorphological data. Although his research on this topic is on-going, there have been several outcomes that are summarized here.

A challenge in paleontology is to use skeletal morphology to infer the ecologies of extinct lineages. To this end, Dr. Grossnickle first examined how jaw shapes of modern mammals correlate with diet, with the ultimate goal of using jaw shapes of fossil mammals to reconstruct their diets. He found that the size of the angular process (located below the jaw joint) is an especially strong correlate of diet; the process is bigger in herbivores and smaller in carnivores. Angular process size can be captured by simple linear measurements and thus can be easily measured in fossil jaws. 

To elucidate mammalian ecological diversity patterns through deep time, Dr. Grossnickle examined fossil mammal jaws of approximately 400 species and measured the angular process size because of its strong association with diet. He acquired these data by visiting several museum specimen collections and measuring hundreds of fossils from the Late Jurassic through Eocene (ca. 160?34 Ma). He calculated morphological disparity (variance) of his measurements as a proxy for ecological diversity, and examined disparity patterns through deep time. Results suggest that therian mammals began to radiate ecologically prior to the K-Pg boundary, contradicting the hypothesis that the mammalian radiation was triggered by the K-Pg mass extinction event.

Further, Dr. Grossnickle sought to perform analyses that incorporate phylogenetic relationships of fossil and modern mammals. To this end, he and his colleagues built an enormous ?metatree? phylogeny, which uses approximately 100 published morphological character matrices and a published phylogeny of modern mammals to generate a phylogeny with thousands of mammalian species, both modern and fossil. This metatree and jaw data are being used to test the timing of the mammalian radiation in light of phylogeny, and it will also be used in multiple future research projects.

Beyond the primary research project funded by the fellowship, Dr. Grossnickle also participated in several tangent projects that utilized similar comparative methods. This includes two projects that tested for convergent evolution among skeletal limb morphologies of mammals of the same locomotor mode (climbing, running, etc.), with a specific focus on gliding mammals.

This NSF fellowship funded Dr. Grossnickle?s involvement in multiple mentorships and outreach programs. Dr. Grossnickle served as a research mentor for several undergraduate students, who gained experience collecting and analyzing morphometric data. Further, he was an instructor and organizer of the Discoveries in Geosciences Field School (University of Washington?s Burke Museum of Natural History & Science), which is a professional development program for K-12 teachers that provides participants with a hands-on paleontology experience. He helped to improve several aspects of the program, such as overhauling the program?s ~50-page guide that is given to all participants. Approximately 30 teachers participated each of the two years during Dr. Grossnickle?s fellowship, meaning that the program indirectly benefitted hundreds of K-12 students.
